UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

"I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Henchmen level and can use equipment like champions, but don't divide experience.

UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: A tall and menacing creature, shrouded in fire, darkness, and shadow.

Sages say the Ophidian were once great pythons, related to the bonefield morelia, but they were changed after generations of nesting near crystal deposits. Those crystals became embedded in their scales. The Ophidian are now over twice as long as their ancestors, and immune to spells. Their bite causes a feeling of numbness and euphoria in the victim; a sensation that helps numb the horror of being swallowed whole.
UnitType.Backstory: Sages say the Ophidian were once great pythons, related to the bonefield morelia, but they were changed after generations of nesting near crystal deposits. Those crystals became embedded in their scales. The Ophidian are now over twice as long as their ancestors, and immune to spells. Their bite causes a feeling of numbness and euphoria in the victim; a sensation that helps numb the horror of being swallowed whole.

UnitType.Description:
Within the third quarto of the Varis Reliquaria is contained the spell Anima Tsal Animana - life from lifelessness. This incantation, first mastered by Ereog in his time of solitude, imbues stone with the semblance of life.
When a Klay Golem is destroyed it reverts back to the rock and sand it was prior to enchantment.
UnitType.Backstory:
Within the third quarto of the Varis Reliquaria is contained the spell Anima Tsal Animana - life from lifelessness. This incantation, first mastered by Ereog in his time of solitude, imbues stone with the semblance of life.
When a Klay Golem is destroyed it reverts back to the rock and sand it was prior to enchantment.

UnitType.Description: In the time before this one - before the coming of the Titans, before the Cataclysm that sundered the world - lesser Elementals such as these served as attendants to Elemental Lords, those who men worshipped as the Five of Anthuane. These creatures were called Anathua for this reason; they were thought to be the physical manifestation of the magic of the shards, which they were never far from. That time has passed and now Storm Elementals serve the Faith Air Cult. Be warned, Storm Elementals are very difficult beings to interact with; they are at best unpredictable. There is one rule of thumb always to be followed: don't ever, ever approach close enough to breathe in parts of its essence.

Vampires move and attack with frightening speed. They can also teleport and suck the blood of their enemies. However, their dislike of fire is so strong that they will refuse to make use of any fire-based equipment.
UnitType.Backstory:
"We are the eternal. So long as we pay the price of our eternal animation, we shall watch and rule for eternity."
-Code of the Nosferatus Imiaris

UnitType.BackStory: Creatures said to be born of a mad mage's dream to mate men and wolves. Unfortunately for her, her dream came true. Combining the speed and strength of wolves with the dexterity (and opposable thumbs) of men, werewolves can close the distance and proceed to slaughter their enemies with ease. Due to their semi-wolf nature, they have an inherent dislike of fire, and as such, refuse to wield or wear any fire based equipment. Too bad that mage never got the chance to fix that.

UnitType.Backstory: In the mountains of Urak, the storm giants long have dwelled. But now they walk abroad, carrying the strange construct of their homes with them, to defend those faithful to the mysterious, omnipresent air.

In the mountains of Urak, the storm giants long have dwelled. But now they walk abroad, carrying the strange construct of their homes with them, to defend those faithful to the mysterious, omnipresent air.

You are the Mountain and you worship Earth. Deep into the tunnels, covered in clay and dust, you've found your path. In the darkness, you've found light. And now you shall bring that darkness all over the surface.

You are the Mountain and you worship Earth. Deep into the tunnels, covered in clay and dust, you've found your path. In the darkness, you've found light. And now you shall bring that darkness all over the surface.

You are of the Sacred Flame and you worship Fire. Empowered in unity, you shall spread across the lands and burn. Forest, flesh, even the hills themselves must be spent to blackness. Only then will the hungering tongues within rest, only when all the waters are fog and the lands are ash.

You are of the Sacred Flame and you worship Fire. Empowered in unity, you shall spread across the lands and burn. Forest, flesh, even the hills themselves must be spent to blackness. Only then will the hungering tongues within rest, only when all the waters are fog and the lands are ash.

These are a primitive and violent people, said by some to be a sub-race of the Fallen, shaped by Curgen in those same years in which the Urxen were first formed. Cave dwellers by nature, the Cataclysm destroyed many of the darklings' original habitats, forcing them to take up a quasi-nomadic way of life. They are dangerous - thieves and killers by nature - and are to be avoided whenever possible, though it is rumored that given the proper incentive, they will form alliances of a sort.

These are a primitive and violent people, said by some to be a sub-race of the Fallen, shaped by Curgen in those same years in which the Urxen were first formed. Cave dwellers by nature, the Cataclysm destroyed many of the darklings' original habitats, forcing them to take up a quasi-nomadic way of life. They are dangerous - thieves and killers by nature - and are to be avoided whenever possible, though it is rumored that given the proper incentive, they will form alliances of a sort.

It's unknown whether those demons are from N'it'Vaganesh or from somewhere else. Rumor has it that they were once of the same race as the Titans but that their essence was drained from them for dark purposes. Anyhow, all that is known for certain is they draw their strength from devouring the life-force of other beings.

These are a primitive and crude people. Often cave dwellers, they are short of stature and violent in nature. In Amarian's journey west, as told by Ezmir, these are called by the scribe a sub-race of Fallen, which may or may not be true.

UnitType.Quote: Air is silent when at peace. Woe to the opponent who hears our wind!
UnitType.Backstory: In the mountains of Urak, the storm giants long have dwelled. But now they walk abroad, carrying the strange construct of their homes with them, to defend those faithful to the mysterious, omnipresent air.

UnitType.Quote: 'Our hammers are earthquakes, our shields are mountains, and we shall turn you to dust.'

UnitType.Quote: "Crackle and bend, singe and smoke. This is the command I give to the land before me."
UnitType.Backstory: This brutish Sovereign has mastered fire and heat. There will never be enough kindling to satisfy him. Those that ally with him, know his designs with you are temporary. He would spare nothing from the furnace, so always hope another is greater foe than you.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in

UnitType.Quote: "Crackle and bend, singe and smoke. This is the command I give to the land before me."
UnitType.Backstory: This brutish Sovereign has mastered the element of fire. He delights in striking down enemies with fire and brimstone, and is most at home wreathed in smoke and shimmering heat.

GameModifier.Provides: -10% Unrest in the city this unit is in
